title: Epic: Milestone Gates and Vertical Slice Delivery
description:
Background:
PLAN.md defines M0-M8 gates. Team execution should map directly to those checkpoints.

Intent:
Create explicit milestone issues that depend on implementation outcomes to provide unambiguous readiness signals.

Scope:
M0-M8 acceptance gates with strict dependency wiring to underlying work items.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Epic dependencies close with demonstrable behavior, not just code presence.
- [ ] User-visible outcomes for this epic are validated in an end-to-end scenario.
- [ ] Operational considerations (testing/monitoring/docs) are captured before closure.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Rationale:
Milestone gates turn planning prose into binary execution checkpoints. This keeps progress measurable and prevents pseudo-completion.

Success signal:
Each milestone closes only when dependency-backed criteria are truly met.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Modeling decision:
We intentionally encoded hierarchy via dependencies (parent item depends on child work) instead of using --parent links, because br parent-child currently makes children depend on parent.

Convention for this backlog:
- Epics/tasks represent roll-up readiness by depending on implementation items.
- Subtasks are executable leaves that unblock parent tasks when closed.

Revisit if br parent semantics evolve.

Outcome:
All later issues can depend on this issue as the baseline contract.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Invariant list includes lifecycle transition guards for tasks, decisions, and artifacts.

- [ ] At least one golden fixture validates end-to-end consistency of these IDs across message types.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Kickoff rationale:
This is the root contract issue for almost every implementation branch. Completing it first minimizes semantic drift and avoids expensive refactors across protocol, scene, and lifecycle models.

Practical outcome:
Once closed, downstream teams can execute in parallel with stable ID/entity semantics.

title: Epic: Contracts, Canonical Models, and Shared Types
description:
Background:
The repo currently defines behavior in docs (PLAN/PROTOCOL/SCENE_MANIFESTS/POI_AND_INTERACTIONS) but has no runtime code yet.

Intent:
Create one canonical source of truth for runtime data contracts so client/server/OpenClaw integration can be implemented without schema drift.

Scope:
- Domain model glossary and IDs
- Shared TypeScript schemas for protocol envelopes and payloads
- Versioning and compatibility rules
- Golden test fixtures for canonical flows

Non-goals:
- No UI polish or rendering work here
- No server runtime logic beyond schema validation scaffolding

Why this matters:
This epic reduces rework by locking down semantics before implementation and protects us from incompatible message formats across components.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Epic dependencies close with demonstrable behavior, not just code presence.
- [ ] User-visible outcomes for this epic are validated in an end-to-end scenario.
- [ ] Operational considerations (testing/monitoring/docs) are captured before closure.
